segments.text: Now, among the awards you have received, which ones have held for you personally the most significance?
Well, awards are strange things.
Once you get the first one, it's easy to get the second one, and it's very easy to get the third one.
And once the dam is broken, they sometimes don't mean a great deal.

We celebrated our centennial year a couple years ago in 1968 and I was very proud to be selected as one of the 15 people that are living and dead that have contributed most to Oregon State University.
And this selection was made by a committee of the faculty and I'm unashamedly proud of being recognized for having changed the direction of the university.
And I think that's the most important one.
Of course, I like my honorary doctor of science.
There aren't too many of those around for researchers of my caliber.
And now, in terms of the direction of your research, which has now seemed to have found itself a niche, are there any research opportunities you've missed?
that you feel a little uneasy about?
Would you have possibly taken something else to task, some other sort of research challenge, if you'd had enough time?
Well, I sort of feel badly that I didn't latch on to one thing and stick with it and become a real expert instead of sort of flopping around.
And this is one of the reasons that I selected what I'm working on now and have stuck with it for five years.
I don't believe that the proper thing is to jump around from one subject to another.
This is sort of an opportunist method of doing research, and I think I would have contributed much more had I stuck to one thing.
Except that oceanographers of your vintage tended to jump from area to area.
Right.
Some things are popular.
Some things you can support at one time.
A lot of it is serendipity.
It just comes unexpected.
Also, I do wish that I was a better mathematician.
I feel limited in my mathematics.
Most of the mathematics that's being used now by the younger modelers wasn't even invented until 10, 15 years ago.
That's true.
What, in your opinion, is the future of the satellite prediction system?
Well, I'm continually amazed at what they can do with satellites.

I would not have believed this anywhere along the line, that they could come up with reasonable near-surface winds, that they could, in effect, look through clouds and find out what's on the other side of them.
After seeing this happen and being skeptical, I just can't see what the end is.
They just keep improving things, and it's just almost like Matthew.
So you're very optimistic about it.
Well, I tell myself they've gone as far as they can go, but they just keep right on going.
So I think that they're going to do more and more.

I sometimes decry the fact that the amounts of money involved in satellites are very large compared to research on land, and I feel that somewhere along the line there might have been a little better division of funds.
I think satellites sometimes are an overkill.
Now,
in directions that oceanography will probably go.
I realize this is a very difficult question.
What advice would you give to a young student at what particular field he should enter, what branch of oceanography, what he should look for?
It's my phone and the secretary.
I have some youngsters to get into.
Well, I think it's a little too bad that quite so many of the brilliant youngsters are getting in strictly theoretical work.
In particular, a tremendous amount of work is going into internal waves of various sizes and kinds.
And I think that we need more people in the middle between theory and practice in the field.
We tend to have descriptive oceanographers on one side to some degree and theoreticians on the other and not too many people in the middle.
And I would advise any student to
to try to get into the wedding theory to what actually is going on in the real world.
Moving away from modeling then, possibly?
Well, if they model, to also do some field work.
And then to go back to sea.
Right.
Do you think with rising ship cost, it's going to be more and more difficult to get ship time to send oceanographers out to sea?
I think it's going to become more and more difficult, but I think it's peanuts compared to other items in the federal budget.
And I think that we're being very penny wise and pound foolish by not supporting more ship time.
Now, there are ships and there are ships.
And I think our money should be going into ships the size of our minimum deep ocean fleet, which is roughly 175 to 200 feet.
These ships can be operated for like a million dollars a year.
I don't think we need any more very large ships, these 300-footers, that don't really do much more than a 150-footer and cost three or four times as much to operate.
So I would like to see a half a dozen more ships the size of the Wicoma if we have any new ships.
And you think then that perhaps we have all of the big research vessels we need for... Well, I do.
I've always...
made this statement whenever I could.
I think we have one or two big ones, and this is about all.
The several that NOAA has is all the country needs.
Okay, that's all I wanted to know.
Now, do you look for more cooperative actions between institutions?
That is, more things like MOPA, oh, that's a poor choice of words, but more deep ocean work with institutions collectively, like Scripps?
This seems to be the direction that things are going.
If you want to do deep ocean work,
Your best chances of funding are to get into one of the IDOE programs and cooperate with someone else.
I'd like to see a balance between individuals doing what they like to do and people who are forced to get under a tent and sort of tailor their research to a larger program.
I think there needs to be a balance.
And I think the balance is pretty good now, and I'd like to see it continue.
OK. And I think if you're not opposed to this kind of deep ocean research, particularly,
Well, not unless it soaks up all the mic.
And I think that right now it's perhaps a 50-50 split or maybe a little bit stronger on the large programs.
And I think that the balance is about where it should be.
It doesn't change much more.
What do you think about the obligations of Oregon State to work more and more inland?
That is, to deal more and more with coastal waters and less and less with the oceans.
State legislatures are putting a tremendous amount of pressure upon state universities.
Well, I think that we would do this if the state had a bigger, well, supplied a greater percentage of our funds.
But historically, the university has paid for teaching and this is all.
We don't have any state funds to speak of.
We get a little bit now and then.
Now, in other states where they have larger programs, like Delaware and Texas and California, they get big chunks of state money to help do this and develop these programs.
There's no way we can do this.
We can't take money from an ONR grant or a contract or an NSF one and do state work.
There's no way.
ONR tells us, get into deep water.
ONR feels that there's enough money going into the coastal areas
area from other sources, so that there's no way we can do this and our hands are kind of tied.

We feel a responsibility to the state, we'd like to do this, we've made abortive efforts several times to get started, but until we can convince some legislators that a unit here at Oregon State would be a good thing,
and would need state support to keep it going, I think that we just sort of have our hands tied.
Now, we have one breakthrough that's coming.
We've done geophysics for the state.
We run the seismographs and do a lot of survey work for the state.
And there are some positions that will be set up and paid for out of state funds, and I think this is a start.
You think that may be a beginning then?
Yeah.
But so far, the problem is getting one or two legislators all hepped up on this, and then it will work.
But until we do this, we haven't done a good job of selling.
Do you look for a reawakened interest in the oceans any time soon?
Well, we've been hollering wolf ever since I can remember, and I think the public may be a little bit tired of this.
Maybe we're at our peak interest now and we'll start going downhill.
Does the current ecology movement bother you in terms of research?
Do you feel uneasy with it?

Well, I feel uneasy with it because I think that we are going to have to support our population, we're going to have to feed it, we're going to have to clothe it, build cars and things like this, and we've got to have a better balance.
I decry stopping a dam that cost $100 million for half a dozen small fish.
An ecologist would shoot me for saying this, but I think we have to have a little bit.
We've bent over backwards to save the environment, and it's cost us a lot of money, and I don't think we can afford it.
Do you feel uneasy with comments like Jacques Cousteau's that the sea's dying?
I don't think he even believes it.
Okay.
The seas are not dying.
As I said before, there are residual pesticides that are a problem.
But aside from that, the oceans are a tremendous reservoir.

Do you see any time in the near or immediate future establishing some kind of a system where sewage is used or really treated sewage or what have you, treated waste is used to feed certain parts of the sea?
Well, this is out of my field, really.
I don't have a thought about it.
That's good enough.
I just wonder if there's been much talk around your university about creating these kinds of things.
None at all within our department.
Okay.
What does your department talk about in terms of research?
What seems to be the direction they wish to take, your younger men in the department?
Well, we have a very interesting, exciting geological program, which is to some degree resource-oriented in the future.
And I think that they will continue with their work, and work of this type is a precursor to getting hard rock minerals out of the ocean.
We did a big study with the University of Hawaii on the Nazca Plate off
western South America that lasted two or three years.
We've done work in rift areas near the Galapagos.
I think eventually it'll become economically feasible to do hard rock mining and I think our people will help with this.
Now, the next series of questions I have are really sort of about oceanographers you've known.
What were they like?
What seemed to be their interests?
What were their characteristics?
if you should like, what kind of cooperation or non-cooperation did you have with them?

About the time you began, oceanography or the direction, if there were a triumphant, if I may say so, development of oceanography, it would have been, of course, Ewing and Revell et al., who were working in the early O&R office.
What kind of recollections do you have of that?
Well, personally, I never had much to do with either Ewing or Revelle.
I met both on a number of occasions.
I find them extremely fascinating people.
They're not only good at what they're doing, but they're knowledgeable in many fields.
I've listened to them both speak a number of times.

I think we were very fortunate to have this type of inspirational leaders in the start, what you might say, in the step function increase in oceanographic research, which took place right after the war.
I think oceanography has to some degree suffered because we've not been a more cohesive political body.

And I've endeavored in the past to try to get some of the labs together to see if we couldn't influence the funding picture to some degree through Congress, and I've found that they're all independents.
They don't want to get together.
And I think this has hurt us to some degree.
What sort of a unit would you conceive of?
Well, I started up the Council of Oceanographic Directors specifically with this in mind about 10 or 15 years ago, and it just died a natural death.
The big labs weren't interested.
The directors didn't even come.
And the smaller labs just weren't politically powerful enough.
We needed scripts in Woods Hole.
And I think if there's one mistake the oceanographers have made, it's not...
to have been a little more political.
Should have combined their interest in terms of lobbying with Congress?
That's right, in a word.
No one of us could do much, but if we were all together, we could have.
Are there any congressmen you should like to cite who have been particularly beneficial towards oceanography?
I've been derelict in not following this closely.
Senator Hollings has done a lot of good, I think, for oceanography.
Some congressmen have done well by their own state laboratories, and I won't mention the closest one.
University of Washington, I think, has been fortunate.
They've done very, very well.

And on the other hand, some of our congressmen have from time to time been able to help us and have always been very cooperative, but we haven't had the powerful committee chairmanship that some other states have had.
I think if we could get California and Massachusetts together with all of us behind it, we could do something.
But I've never been able to get people going.
Think it's because Cripps and Woods Hole have pretty well dominated the field of oceanography?
Well, they feel that they're powerful enough in their own right, and they don't want to get together with anybody else.
Simple as that.
Now, in terms of, let's say, while we're talking about these loose historic figures in oceanography,
What do you think were the major breakthroughs that occurred in oceanography in your period of active research?
If you were to turn to a student and say, look, this is what oceanography has done and this is why it was exciting, what would you cite?
Well, of course, the biggest breakthrough has been the automation of data collection.
I remember lecturing in 1947 and stating, after he'd just come back from the cruise and he had 800 data points, he said, we just got too damn much data.
And now a student will go out and come back with 2 million data points.
Now, he could not have gotten that much data then.
And he couldn't have done anything with it without computers.
So it's the electronic system of gathering data and sensors and recording it, and then the electronic system of processing it.
And without those two, I don't think we've gotten anywhere.
Oceanography had no breakthroughs and was very primitive from the time of Nansen up until the time of Swerter.
And then just within four or five years, we started.
I think the first computer was used in a major oceanographic program, something like 1947.
And that's only 20 years.
And now our students feel absolutely put upon if they don't have a $10,000 budget for computers over the time they're getting their degrees.
It costs about that, roughly that much on average for a physical oceanographic student.
And along with this have come new mathematics, time series analysis, Fourier transforms, all of these things, which just weren't used when I was going to school.
We'd never even heard of them.
So you think technological innovations, then?
Right.
Well, I would agree with that, by the way.
Let me...
Ravel said that when he was asked what he had contributed, he thought, he said, I sent Scripps to sea, which may have been an overstatement.
No, I think that's a good statement.
And when Nirenberg was asked what his contribution to Scripps had been, he said, I brought to Scripps computers.
Now, what I want to ask you is, in a short, pithy statement like that, what's your contribution been to Oregon State?
What would you say?
Oh, heavens, I don't know.
Look around you.
I think that if I did anything, it was I was able to organize a minimum amount of resources and produce with it.
And by doing this and continuing to do it, I obtained support.
And our growth was rather phenomenal.
And it wouldn't have been this unless I'd had some organizational quality.
So you think...
Your primary contribution to Oregon State then was in terms of organization?
Organization and getting the most out of the minimal amount of resources.
So it could be I brought oceanography to Oregon State then.
That's good enough, yeah.
Yeah, there's no question about that.
And what about in terms of your research?
What do you think are the most important things you've done in terms of research?
Oh, I don't think I've had any breakthroughs of any kind, really.
I think my research is pedestrian and descriptive.
but I think we need all kinds.

When I was in graduate school, I was about ready to quit because I didn't have any flashes of genius compared to Walter Monks, and I went to see Svirt at one time, and all of a sudden I thought, well, I really didn't think I was up to it.

And Svirt up to a big pyramid, and he says, for every genius up here, we've got three or four guys, sub-genius, and we get down, and wherever you are on the pyramid, as long as you're doing your best, you're needed, because it takes the whole thing to keep the business going.
And I think that we need all types of researchers.
And I do the best I can.
And I don't think that it's been anything startling.
But nevertheless, physical, I don't know how you can, one of the, you know, you realize I'm a rank outsider in this field, okay, and absolutely a baby in the woods.

But one of the things that bothers me is there seems to be a drop in physical oceanography and in systematics, for example, outside of physical oceanography in terms of just classification of organisms.
students don't seem to be willing to do these kinds of things.
How can you do oceanography if these things are not done?
Shouldn't there be some kind of a move towards basics in your field, towards students who are willing to collect and describe?
Well, I think so, but the tendency is not to fund this sort of thing.
I don't think the problem is so much the students or the laboratories.
I think the problem is in the peer review system that NSF employs.
If you put in for purely descriptive purposes,
pedestrian type research proposal, your chances of getting it are not really too good.
And unless you've got a theory all worked out and practically have all the solutions before you start, your chances of getting money for this type of work are getting harder all the time.
Now, there are a few stars that continue to get
money for this, but I think that the numbers are disproportionate, because most of the younger guys are theoretical, and if you don't have some theory in there, your chances are fairly slim.
Now, this may be sour grapes, but I think it's a fact.
Are you unhappy with the peer review system of the NSF?
I think it's the best we could have.
I'm not unhappy with it, no.
No, I'm not unhappy with it.
To those of us in the field of history, if I may ask you to draw some comparisons here, we sometimes feel that we're in the provinces.
if you allow this, we teach at UT, that people from Harvard and Yale tend to get the grants because of a sort of an in-group, if you should like.
Do you feel that possibly the same sort of discrimination is applied to the people in the sciences?
That is, the bigger laboratories and the bigger oceanographic institutions seem to have better luck finding grants for their students or financing their research?
Well, I can't complain because I've been able to work with the system and do all right.
I'll withdraw that question.
If I were to ask you, and which I intend to, what you considered your major accomplishments in your academic and scholarly career, what would you list?
Well, just making this place go.
All right.
This is it.
OK. Aside from that, I think that I've added bits and pieces of descriptive material to a number of different fields, which are all part of the mosaic
But nothing's darling.
But then I think then that you would agree that when Fleming says his major thing was establishing an apartment at the University of Washington.
Right.
My major thing is the same.
Your major thing was establishing one at Oregon State.
And I want to make sure we get this on tape because it's hard for a student, I think, to realize it.
But that's, in effect, bringing oceanography to a place it had not been before, the Pacific Northwest, a point you've never really made clear, I don't think.
Yes, I think this is true.

Because all the work had been done in Southern California, in Massachusetts, been no really Texas coastal work done or work done in the Pacific Northwest to speak of until these institutions came here.
Okay.
And this is the second one.
The Chesapeake Bay Institute, Don Pritchard and I started that from Holcroft, too.
And it was the same sort of thing on the East Coast.
I really wasn't aware of that.
Right.
I guess that was the first oceanographic institution to be established
After the war.
After the war, to work those estuaries, is that right?
Right, right, 1948.
See, Columbia was set up about sometime during the war.
Miami was set up a little bit before that.
But then Johns Hopkins, Texas A&M, Oregon State, Alaska, Hawaii, just warm fell in right after that.
Now...
I want to ask a couple of things about the Chesapeake Bay along that way, because as I say, I'm confessing to you very quickly.

Had there not been any work done then along that part of the... Well, at Solomon's Island and at Gloucester Point, Virginia and Maryland each had a marine biological station, which was a summer station that did a little bit of hydrographic work, but not a great deal.
And if they had been fulfilling the need that was there, then the states certainly wouldn't have given Johns Hopkins $30,000 apiece to start up a new laboratory.
But they were mainly classical marine biological stations.
Oh, okay.
When you began to organize this new laboratory, what did you tell yourself the first thing was that you needed?
Oh, we've got to get a boat first.
So we bought a little boat.
And then we...
had one built.
We had a fleet, I think, of three or four small boats.
The biggest one was perhaps 25, 30 tons, 60 feet long.
And then we started out doing hydrographic and chemical work on the estuary and covered it pretty well for three or four years.
And did you work primarily there with government contracts?
It wouldn't seem likely to me.
Well, we got $30,000 from ONR, $30,000 from
and $30,000 from Maryland, and that was a lot of money in those days.

Then along came the Korean War, interest surged, a committee came around and asked us how much could we grow, and Pritchard said some number out of his head, I think it was $200,000, so we got a $200,000 jump at that time, and then that's where the institute really began to develop.
Did you try to bring in young scholars to work there?
Did you get postdocs and this sort of thing?
Well, postdocs in oceanography weren't as popular then as they are now.
And part of this reflects the job situation.
Then anybody could go get a job.
You didn't have to be a postdoc.
There was no particular advantage, unless you particularly wanted to study with some individual.
Now jobs are a little harder to get so that there are more people that are using postdocs as an interim thing.
At least that's my impression.
Maybe extra.
It seems like now almost all scientists go off on a postdoc for a while, and I've often wondered why that.
So I think it's a good idea, and a few of our students have gone on postdocs and then come back to work at Oregon State.
And I think, by and large, they've benefited by it.
Now, when you get this $200,000 jump all of a sudden in your budget, then what do you do?
Well, we scramble around and hire some people.
I don't know.
If you're on a small budget, then you sort of dream and think about what you do, and then you have certain plans in the back of your mind.
For example, when I had nothing here, I went to the Ford Foundation and asked for $60,000 to buy a small boat.
The Ford Foundation sent a panel out.
They looked the place over.
and came back and said, the place has absolutely no chance of development.
Went down to Scripps and gave him $3 million for a new biological program.
And this was about 1957.
So I did have ship plans and ideas
no real long-range plan, but had various alternates that I could do, and this is what I did.
I had these ready to go when the money became available in the early 60s.
And then you just said, okay, now the money's here, we'll do this.
And with a particular set of priorities, I take it, beginning each time with vessels.
Right.
You have to have a vessel.
That's the first thing.
Did your experience at Chesapeake Bay, did this help to shape your administrative experience when you arrived here at Oregon State?
I think so, yeah.
You think that
You made your mistakes up there, so to speak?

Well, actually, I had two or three years of administrative experience at Scripps with the BT section, and at the start of the war, I caught pneumonia, so I couldn't get into the service, and I worked for a shipyard in Portland, and they were so desperate for people that if you could read a blueprint, you were an automatic engineer, so I had...
Eight or ten people working under me in an engineering capacity and had charge of building the sub-assemblies for 30 LSTs and a bunch of carriers.
And this was a good experience and one that I normally wouldn't have gotten at that age.
And then three years in the Navy was all a good experience.
So that I had had administrative experience for five or six years before I got into oceanography.
When you get your first commission, let's say, in terms of money to build a vessel, do you design it?
Well, I've got the best architect I could, but actually, largely I design the vessels that I've worked on.
I'd rather do that than anything I can think of.
Oh, okay.
And I know this is a naive question, but what's the first thing you begin to look for when you start to design it?
Do you say, what's the biggest thing I can get for the money?
Oh, okay, that's the way we begin.
All right, for example, I got $250,000, which I should have been satisfied to build a 65-foot vessel with.
I've managed to get another $50,000 of return overhead.
That gave me $300,000.
And then I shot for an 80-foot.
Well, the size goes up to the cube of the length.
And instead of getting a vessel that would be extremely limited, I built the Ocona, which is operating out of Alaska now.
And it's doing a fine job.
The first thing I look for, first of all, you have to have a vessel that will do the work you want.
But then I'd look for creature comfort.
Make the quarters as good as I can, the eating facilities as good as I can.
People are out there crowded on a small vessel for a long period of time, and they need creature comfort if you can possibly give it to them.
And I think one of the reasons our people seem to be happy on our ships is that we've tried to do this.
Worked for Living Corps.
When you're on the ship now, if you're out on the voyage, do you still go through the whole process of pulling watches and the whole business as one once did when one was a student on the vessels?
Well, you do stand watches, but as a senior citizen, I avoid it if I can.
I just do what I'm out there to do.
But for example, on the Japanese ship, I didn't stand any watches because we had about 50 students and other scientific personnel.
On the British ship, I stand regular watches.
I don't do any real hard work, but there's always something going on around the clock.
And I usually work about 8, 12 hours a day.
is awfully hard to meet.
Well, what sort of innovations have taken places in the ships themselves?
What are the most important things to have been done to the ships in terms of facilitating research, except computers?
The most important single thing is a satellite navigator.
A satellite navigator.
There were times when you didn't know within 20 miles where you were in bad weather over a long period of time.
And then we got Loran, which was reasonably good.
